Here for ER follow up for head injury, complaining of pain in back
Acompanied by dad. Pt presents today for an ER follow up from O5lO2l24 for head/neck injury. Pt was diving into the
shallow end of a pool at friend's house on 04128124 when her head hit the bottom. Pt reports that she thought she
was standing closer to the deep end of the pool but it was shallow. Pt has had continued head, neck, and mid back
pain. Dad reports that on 05101124 that pt started complaining out feel mentally foggy and having an "out of body"
experience. Dad states that pt did not have bruising until 05/02124.P|had bruised on the top of her head and behind
her ears. Pt has had trouble sleeping. Dad states that her normal ways of carrying herself is different. Pt had a CT of
the brain, Cspine, and Tspine and all were normal. Pt complains of pain when laying down and trying to sit in a seated
position. Pt has difficulty bending over to do simple tasks like tying her shoes. Pt had a panic attack two days ago that
does not normally occur. Pt is currently taking lbuprofen and Tylenol for pain.

patients continue to experience pressure over the forehead or cheekbones, congestion and cough until they have
been on antibiotics for 5-7 days. Please follow our directions regarding treatment of symptoms lf you are not noticing
improvement or if symptoms are worsening, please call our office. Additional information can be found at:

FLU
You were seen in our office today for the flu or flu-like illness. lnfluenza illnesses are caused by viruses; antibiotics are
not indicated. Children with flu may appear uncomfortable and experience high fever, cough, congestion, body aches
and nausea/vomiting. lt is important that your child drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration and get plenty of rest.
Acetaminophen or ibuprofen can be used for fever/discomfort according to our instructions. Do NOT use any
medications containing aspirin. ln selected patient we may discuss the use of anti-viral medications which may
shorten the duration of symptoms. These anti-viral medicines only work if started in the very beginning of the illness.
The flu generally lasts for 7-10 days. Call our office if your child is acting very ill, having trouble breathing or you have
concerns. Additional information may be available at:
